description: First used as a noun in Early Modern English, from dialectal English dold (“stupid, confused”), from Middle English dold, a variant of dulled, dult (“dulled”), past participle of dullen, dollen (“to make dull, make stupid”), from dull, dul, dwal (“stupid”). More at dull.

entries.meaning: (derogatory) A stupid person; a blockhead or dullard.

verbs.description: dolt (third-person singular simple present dolts, present participle dolting, simple past and past participle dolted)
